awd_titl_txt: From Approximate to Exact Designs with Applications to Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Design of experiments is an integral part of the scientific process in many areas of research with a direct impact on society, such as the biological sciences, the health sciences, the social sciences, engineering, marketing, and education.  A well-chosen design facilitates the collection of data that, at a minimum cost, maximizes the information for the scientific questions of interest.  Many scientific studies allow for repeated use of conceptual units, so that developing tools for optimal design for these problems has great potential impact.  Particularly in the realm of big data, there is much room for improvement of existing methods for design of experiments, and the tools and concepts under development in this research project have potential to lead to significant gain of information without increasing computational cost.  Results from the project will be made available to researchers in other areas through easy-to-use software that implements the algorithms to be developed. Graduate students will be trained to become researchers in design of experiments. 

This project aims to result in a major leap forward in understanding and knowledge of optimal design of experiments. Recent work in the field has had a significant impact on the advancement of optimal crossover designs and designs for interference models for arbitrarily given covariance structures and design size configurations. However, these results have for the most part been limited to approximate designs for relatively simple models. While these results are arguably important in their own right, this project will extend methods and tools to achieve the ultimate goal of deriving exact designs for a wider spectrum of practical models. The results will be a much needed addition to our collective design toolbox. Most importantly, this project will go beyond the territory of design and apply the tools and ideas from design of experiments to subsampling problems emerging in big data with both statistical and machine learning methods under consideration. Preliminary results indicate that this is an opportune time to make these challenging but critical steps.

por.por_cntn:
The research effort has been largely devoted to finding optimal designs of experiment for crossover and interference models. In crossover designs, each human or animal subject receives a sequence of treatments over multiple periods of time. Such design has the benefit of saving experimental resources to get more information about the treatment effect through within subject comparison. This design is very popular in clinical trials, especially when the effect of treatments are short-lived and reversible. It is best suited to trials related to symptomatic but chronic conditions or diseases such as neurology, psychiatry, and pain treatment. Out of the 519 PubMed-indexed randomized trials published in December 2000, 22% of them used crossover designs. Beyond clinical trials, the crossover design has also been applied on cattle, animal feeding, psychology, biological assay, sensory testing, occupational stress, bioequivalence, industry, diets and milling of paper. The design for interference model is applicable when a treatment assigned to a plot also have impact on the response of its neighboring plots, especially when the plots are small. Such neighbor effects naturally exist in serology, agriculture, horticulture, and forestry experiments, where the treatment could be a plant variety, fertilizer, irrigation, or pesticide. In crop experiments, the neighbor effects could be due to competition for light, poaching of nutrients by plant roots as well as spread of disease pathogens. Particularly, the competition effect could associated with height difference, tillering ability, date to maturity, canopy size and root yield, respectively. The literature also exhibits its application on oil-seed rape, insect, kale, potatoes, cassava, disease screening, forest, fruit trees and sunflowers.

 

The PI have established a systematic method for studying optimal designs for crossover models and interference models. The traditional combinatorial method for these problems are subject to the problem of inflexibility. That means the proposed designs may only exist for a certain configurations of the numbers of blocks, treatments and the length of each block. Also they need to assume certain structure for the covariance matrix of the observations within a block, normally proportional to the identity matrix. The approximate design theory that I have developed are allow one to easily find optimal or efficient designs for any design configuration and any within-block covariance matrix. An integer programing is also introduced to derive exact designs from the theoretical approximate designs. Such method is universal and can be easily extended to any other models that have not been studied in the published papers.

 

A new direction is explored on the incomplete U-statistic. It tries to solve the computational issue of the U-statistic which requires the enumeration of all unit combinations. The solution is to design a sampling mechanism to take a representative portion of unit combinations so that the information is still maintained however at a reduced computational cost. The proposed method was shown to be better than existing methods by magnitudes. Its theoretical performance are thoroughly studied, which is supported by empirical results. We also further extended it to the supreme of incomplete U-statistics with an application to the economic topic of stochastic monotonicity test. 

 

Also contributions are made to the active learning method, where the relabeling of a unit is expensive and one has to carefully choose the unit to be labeled. The PI found its connection to the traditional approximate design theory through a KKT argument on a penalized information maximization problem. Theoretical justification is provided for this continuous approximation to the original NP-hard combinatorial problem. Algorithms are developed and shown to be more efficient than existing ones by magnitudes. 

 

For the duration of this project, there are 6 accepted publications with two in annals of statistics and one in JASA. There are additional five manuscripts produced during this period and currently under review.
